title: Volkswagen recall: British cars to be called back as boss admits 'We totally screwed up'
text:
Volkswagen recall: British cars to be called back as boss admits 'We totally screwed up' Volkswagen recall: British cars to be called back as boss admits 'We totally screwed up' THE boss of Volkswagen admitted the carmaker "totally screwed up" as he apologised for rigging emissions tests, in a scandal which could see millions of diesel cars in Britain recalled. PUBLISHED: 10:32, Tue, Sep 22, 2015 | UPDATED: 13:56, Tue, Sep 22, 2015 REUTERS / GETTY Millions of British Volkswagens could be recalled 
Europe's largest car brand faces a criminal investigation and up to £11.6billion ($18bn) in fines after it rigged diesel vehicles to pass US emissions tests, according to the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). 
And now the brand, which is in the same group as Audi, Skoda, Seat, Bentley and Lamborghini, has admitted that up to 11million of its cars could have cheated their way through worldwide standards, including Britain and Europe. 
The company also revealed today that it's setting aside £4.7bn (€6.5bn) to cover the costs relating to the crisis. US head of VW, Michael Horn last night said: "Our company was dishonest with the EPA, and the California Air Resources Board and with all all of you."And in my German words: We have totally screwed up."We must fix the cars to prevent his from ever happening again and we have to make this right. "This kind of behaviour is totally inconsistent with our qualities."The carmaker is to recall half a million US diesel cars sold between 2009 and 2015 that were fitted a 'detect device' that allowed models to pass tests. However, during normal driving the cars give off between 10 and 40 times the legal pollution limit, according to the EPA.Volkswagen Passat, Golf, Beetles and Jetta, as well as Audi A3s, are thought to be among the affected models. Related articles Solar panels payouts to be sliced by huge 90% from January 
The US Justice department has also launched a probe into the scandal. 
The carmaker is now expected to announce a recall of some of its diesel-powered cars that have been sold in Britain. 
In a statement on Tuesday it said: "Further internal investigations conducted to date have established that the relevant engine management software is also installed in other Volkswagen Group vehicles with diesel engines." 
Clean vehicles manager at T&E Greg Archer told City AM: "There is strong evidence that similar illegal devices are also used in Europe by both VW and other manufacturers."Since 2009, when VW began using defeat devices, over 40 million diesel cars have been sold in Europe, a sixth of all cars on the road today." 
It comes as South Korea declared it is to re-examine VW's diesel cars in a sign that the crisis is set to have knock-on affects outside the US. Shares in the Frankfurt-listed company sank by 19 per cent on Monday, and lost a further 20 per cent on Tuesday. In reaction to the US cheating claims, Volkswagen chief executive Martin Winterkorn said: "I personally am deeply sorry that we have broken the trust of our customers and the public. "Volkswagen has ordered an external investigation of this matter." Related articles
